notes: First 150 questions for GCSE Computer Science (UK) — Computer Systems & Theory. Fields align with Firestore seed requirements.

questions.stem: What is hardware?
options: Physical components of a computer system
Programs and data stored on a computer
questions.explanation: Hardware means the physical parts you can touch (e.g., CPU, RAM, keyboard).

questions.stem: Which of these is an input device?
questions.explanation: Input devices send data into the computer.

questions.stem: Which of these is an output device?
questions.explanation: Output devices present information to the user.

questions.stem: A scanner is best described as…
questions.explanation: A scanner captures physical documents/photos and inputs them as data.

questions.stem: A musician wants to record vocals on a computer. Which device is needed?
questions.explanation: A microphone captures sound and inputs it into the computer.

questions.stem: Why is a GPU useful for graphics-heavy tasks?
options: It is designed for many parallel calculations used in graphics
It converts domain names to IP addresses
questions.explanation: GPUs are built for parallel processing, which helps with rendering and some compute workloads.

questions.stem: Which of these is application software?
questions.explanation: Application software helps users perform tasks (e.g., word processing).

questions.stem: Which of these is system software?
questions.explanation: System software manages hardware and provides services for applications.

questions.stem: Utility software is mainly used to…
options: Maintain, protect, or manage a computer system
questions.explanation: Utilities support the system (e.g., antivirus, backup tools).

questions.stem: Which is a utility program?
questions.explanation: Antivirus is a utility that helps protect and maintain the system.

questions.stem: A device driver is best described as…
options: System software that lets the OS communicate with hardware
questions.explanation: Drivers translate OS requests into device-specific commands.

questions.stem: Firmware is usually stored in…
questions.explanation: Firmware must persist without power, so it is stored in non-volatile memory.

questions.stem: What does CPU stand for?
questions.explanation: CPU stands for Central Processing Unit.

questions.stem: Which CPU component carries out arithmetic and logic operations?
questions.explanation: The ALU performs arithmetic and logic operations.

questions.stem: Which CPU component coordinates the activities of the CPU?
questions.explanation: The Control Unit manages control signals and timing.

questions.stem: Registers are…
options: Small, very fast storage inside the CPU
questions.explanation: Registers are tiny ultra-fast storage locations inside the CPU.

questions.stem: Cache memory is mainly used to…
options: Hold frequently used data/instructions close to the CPU
Convert domain names to IP addresses
questions.explanation: Cache reduces CPU waiting time by storing frequently used data/instructions.

questions.stem: Why are registers faster than RAM?
options: They are stored on the hard drive
They are located inside the CPU and accessed directly
questions.explanation: Registers are inside the CPU, so access is extremely fast.

questions.stem: Which is generally fastest for CPU access?
questions.explanation: Cache is designed to be very fast and sits close to the CPU.

questions.stem: In the fetch-decode-execute cycle, what happens during FETCH?
options: The instruction is translated into signals
The next instruction is retrieved from memory
questions.explanation: Fetch retrieves the next instruction from memory (usually RAM).

questions.stem: In the fetch-decode-execute cycle, what happens during DECODE?
options: The instruction is interpreted into control signals
questions.explanation: Decode interprets the instruction so the CPU knows what to do.

questions.stem: In the fetch-decode-execute cycle, what happens during EXECUTE?
questions.explanation: Execute performs the instruction (ALU operation, read/write, etc.).

questions.stem: Clock speed is measured in…
questions.explanation: Clock speed is cycles per second, commonly in GHz.

questions.stem: Which is the best reason a higher clock speed can improve performance?
options: More CPU cycles can occur per second
questions.explanation: Higher clock speed can allow more operations per second.

questions.stem: Why doesn't doubling clock speed always double performance?
options: Other bottlenecks (memory, storage, software) can limit gains
questions.explanation: Performance depends on the whole system and how software uses it.

questions.stem: Which factor can improve multitasking the most?
questions.explanation: More cores help with parallel workloads and multitasking.

questions.stem: Two CPUs have the same clock speed. CPU A has 8 cores and CPU B has 4 cores. Which workload benefits most from CPU A?
options: Running many apps and background tasks at once
questions.explanation: More cores help when many tasks can run in parallel.

questions.stem: A PC is slow when opening files and loading apps, but fine once open. Most likely upgrade?
questions.explanation: Loading times are often limited by storage performance.

questions.stem: RAM stands for…
questions.explanation: RAM is Random Access Memory.

questions.stem: RAM is best described as…
options: Main working memory used by running programs
questions.explanation: RAM holds data/instructions currently being used.

questions.stem: RAM is…
questions.explanation: Volatile memory loses its contents when power is removed.

questions.stem: ROM is…
questions.explanation: ROM stores firmware and does not lose data when power is off.

questions.stem: Why is ROM suitable for storing boot instructions?
options: It keeps data when power is off
questions.explanation: Boot instructions must be available at startup even without power.

questions.stem: What is virtual memory?
options: Using secondary storage as an extension of RAM
questions.explanation: Virtual memory uses part of storage as extra memory when RAM is full.

questions.stem: Why does a computer slow down when it runs out of RAM?
options: It starts using virtual memory on storage, which is slower
questions.explanation: Using storage as virtual memory is much slower than RAM.

questions.stem: A laptop loses unsaved work when the battery dies. Which component caused this loss?
questions.explanation: Unsaved work is in volatile RAM and is lost without power.

questions.stem: Which storage device usually has no moving parts?
questions.explanation: SSDs use flash memory and have no moving parts.

questions.stem: Which is typically cheaper per GB?
questions.explanation: HDDs are usually cheaper per GB than SSDs.

questions.stem: Which storage type uses magnetic platters?
questions.explanation: HDDs store data magnetically on spinning platters.

questions.stem: Which is an example of optical storage?
questions.explanation: Blu-ray is optical storage read using lasers.

questions.stem: Which is an example of flash storage?
questions.explanation: USB sticks are flash storage.

questions.stem: A school replaces HDDs with SSDs. Which improvement is most likely?
questions.explanation: SSDs have faster access times than HDDs.

questions.stem: A laptop is dropped often. Best storage choice to reduce damage risk?
questions.explanation: SSDs are more shock-resistant because they have no moving parts.

questions.stem: Secondary storage is mainly used for…
options: Long-term storage of files and programs
questions.explanation: Secondary storage is non-volatile and stores data long term.

questions.stem: An embedded system is…
options: A computer system built into another device for a specific function
questions.explanation: Embedded systems are designed for a dedicated purpose inside a larger product.

questions.stem: Which is MOST likely an embedded system?
questions.explanation: Smart appliances commonly use embedded systems.

questions.stem: Why are embedded systems often power-efficient?
options: They run many apps at once
They are optimised for one task with limited resources
questions.explanation: Embedded systems are designed for low power, cost, and specific functions.

questions.stem: An operating system is…
options: System software that manages hardware and provides services for applications
questions.explanation: The OS manages hardware and allows applications to run.

questions.stem: Which OS function organises files on storage?
questions.explanation: File management handles folders, saving, naming, and permissions.

questions.stem: Which OS function controls hardware devices like printers and keyboards?
questions.explanation: Device management uses drivers to communicate with hardware.

questions.stem: How does an OS create the illusion that many programs run at once on a single-core CPU?
options: By time slicing (rapidly switching CPU time between processes)
questions.explanation: Time slicing gives each process a short time slot so it appears simultaneous.

questions.stem: GUI stands for…
questions.explanation: GUI uses windows, icons and menus.

questions.stem: CLI stands for…
questions.explanation: CLI is text-based interaction using typed commands.

questions.stem: Why might an expert prefer a CLI?
options: It can be faster and more automatable with commands and scripts
It is required for all computers
questions.explanation: CLI can be efficient and scriptable for experienced users.

questions.stem: LAN stands for…
questions.explanation: A LAN covers a small area like a home or school.

questions.stem: WAN stands for…
questions.explanation: A WAN covers a large area; the internet is a WAN.

questions.stem: Which device connects multiple networks together?
questions.explanation: Routers connect networks and route packets between them.

questions.stem: Which device connects devices within a LAN and forwards frames efficiently?
questions.explanation: Switches connect devices in a LAN and forward data to the correct device.

questions.stem: Bandwidth is best described as…
options: Maximum data transfer rate of a connection
questions.explanation: Bandwidth is capacity/rate, often measured in bits per second.

questions.stem: Latency is best described as…
options: Delay in data transmission (time taken to travel)
questions.explanation: Latency is delay, often experienced as lag.

questions.stem: In a client-server model, the server…
questions.explanation: Servers provide resources (files, websites, printers) to clients.

questions.stem: Peer-to-peer networks are characterised by…
options: A central dedicated server for all resources
Devices sharing resources directly without a central server
questions.explanation: In P2P, devices can share resources directly and act as both client and server.

questions.stem: In a star topology, what happens if one cable to a PC fails?
options: The router becomes an access point
questions.explanation: In a star, each device has its own link; one link failure affects only that device.

questions.stem: In a star topology, what happens if the central switch fails?
questions.explanation: The central device is a single point of failure in star topology.

questions.stem: Packet switching means…
options: Data is sent as one continuous stream with a reserved path
Data is split into packets that may take different routes
Data is stored only on ROM
questions.explanation: Data is split into packets which can take different routes and be reassembled at the destination.

questions.stem: One advantage of packet switching is…
options: If a route fails, packets can be rerouted
questions.explanation: Packets can be routed around failures or congestion.

questions.stem: An IP address is…
options: A unique device address on a network
questions.explanation: IP addresses identify devices for routing across networks.

questions.stem: A MAC address is…
options: A device’s hardware address for its network interface
questions.explanation: MAC addresses identify network interfaces (hardware-level) on a LAN.

questions.stem: DNS is used to…
options: Convert domain names to IP addresses
questions.explanation: DNS translates domain names (like example.com) to IP addresses.

questions.stem: A protocol is…
options: A set of rules for communication between devices
questions.explanation: Protocols define how data is formatted and transmitted.

questions.stem: Which protocol is used to view web pages?
questions.explanation: HTTP/HTTPS is used for web browsing.

questions.stem: What does HTTPS add compared to HTTP?
questions.explanation: HTTPS uses TLS to encrypt traffic and protect against interception/tampering.

questions.stem: Which protocol is commonly used to send email between servers?
questions.explanation: SMTP is used to send email between mail servers.

questions.stem: Which protocol is commonly used to transfer files?
questions.explanation: FTP is used for file transfer.

questions.stem: TCP is responsible for…
options: Reliable transmission with error checking and retransmission
questions.explanation: TCP provides reliable delivery, ordering, and error checking.

questions.stem: IP is responsible for…
options: Routing packets to the correct destination across networks
questions.explanation: IP handles addressing and routing between networks.

questions.stem: Malware is…
options: Malicious software designed to harm systems or steal data
questions.explanation: Malware includes viruses, worms, trojans, spyware and more.

questions.stem: A virus typically…
options: Replicates by attaching to a host file/program
questions.explanation: Viruses attach to a host and usually need to be executed to spread.

questions.stem: A worm typically…
options: Needs a host file to spread
Spreads on its own over networks
questions.explanation: Worms self-replicate across networks without a host file.

questions.stem: A trojan is…
questions.explanation: Trojans trick users into installing them by looking legitimate.

questions.stem: Phishing is…
options: Tricking users into revealing sensitive information
questions.explanation: Phishing uses fake messages/websites to steal credentials.

questions.stem: A DoS attack aims to…
options: Prevent access to a service by overwhelming it
questions.explanation: A Denial of Service attack overloads a system so legitimate users cannot access it.

questions.stem: A firewall helps by…
options: Monitoring and controlling incoming/outgoing network traffic
questions.explanation: Firewalls filter traffic based on rules to block unauthorised access.

questions.stem: Encryption helps by…
options: Scrambling data so only authorised parties can read it
questions.explanation: Encryption makes data unreadable without the key.

questions.stem: Why are software updates important for security?
questions.explanation: Updates often patch security holes that attackers exploit.

questions.stem: A user gets an email 'from IT' asking to reset their password via a link. Best action?
options: Verify via official IT channel and check sender/domain
questions.explanation: This is typical phishing—verify independently rather than using the provided link.

questions.stem: Two-factor authentication (2FA) means…
options: Using two different types of evidence to verify identity
questions.explanation: 2FA combines factors (e.g., password + one-time code/biometric).

questions.stem: In the UK, laws about personal data are mainly covered by…
questions.explanation: UK GDPR and the Data Protection Act govern how organisations process personal data.

questions.stem: Personal data is…
options: Any file stored on a computer
Information that can identify a person
questions.explanation: Personal data relates to an identifiable individual (e.g., name, email).

questions.stem: Software piracy is…
questions.explanation: Piracy violates copyright/licensing terms.

questions.stem: An ethical issue is…
options: A moral concern about right and wrong behaviour
questions.explanation: Ethics concerns what should be done, not only what is legal.

questions.stem: E-waste refers to…
questions.explanation: E-waste is discarded electronics; it may contain toxic materials.

questions.stem: Why is recycling electronics beneficial?
options: It reduces landfill and recovers valuable materials
questions.explanation: Recycling reduces environmental harm and conserves resources.

questions.stem: Binary is a base…
questions.explanation: Binary uses base 2 with digits 0 and 1.

questions.stem: Denary (decimal) is a base…
questions.explanation: Denary is base 10.

questions.stem: Hexadecimal is a base…
questions.explanation: Hexadecimal uses base 16 (0–9, A–F).

questions.stem: ASCII is used to represent…
questions.explanation: ASCII assigns numbers to characters.

questions.stem: Unicode is important because it…
options: Supports many more characters and languages than ASCII
questions.explanation: Unicode supports a wider range of characters for different languages and symbols.

questions.stem: A 10×10 image with colour depth 3 bits. Minimum size (bits)?
questions.explanation: 10×10=100 pixels. 100×3 bits=300 bits (ignoring headers/compression).

questions.stem: If an image uses 12 colours, minimum bits per pixel needed?
questions.explanation: Need at least 12 codes. 4 bits gives 16 possible values (2^4).

questions.stem: Sound sampled at 8,000 Hz, 8-bit depth, 1 channel, duration 2 s. Size (bytes)?
questions.explanation: Samples=8000×2=16000. 8-bit=1 byte. 1 channel → 16000 bytes.

questions.stem: What is lossy compression?
options: Compression that keeps all original data
Compression that removes some data permanently to reduce size
questions.explanation: Lossy compression discards some information (e.g., JPEG, MP3).

questions.stem: What is lossless compression?
options: Keeps all information so the original can be perfectly restored
questions.explanation: Lossless compression allows perfect reconstruction (e.g., PNG, ZIP).

questions.stem: Which register holds the address of the next instruction to be fetched?
questions.explanation: The Program Counter stores the address of the next instruction.

questions.stem: The MAR is used to…
options: Store data being processed by the ALU
Store the address in memory that the CPU wants to access
questions.explanation: The MAR holds the address of the memory location to read/write.

questions.stem: The MDR is used to…
options: Store data/instructions being transferred to or from memory
questions.explanation: The MDR holds data read from memory or to be written to memory.

questions.stem: Why does increasing cache size sometimes improve performance?
options: More frequently used data fits close to the CPU, reducing slow RAM access
questions.explanation: More cache can increase cache hits and reduce time waiting for RAM.

questions.stem: What is 'interrupt handling' in an operating system?
options: Responding to signals/events that require CPU attention (e.g., keyboard input)
questions.explanation: Interrupts let hardware/software request immediate attention from the CPU.

questions.stem: A computer freezes when one app crashes. What OS feature helps prevent this?
questions.explanation: Memory protection isolates processes so one crash is less likely to affect others.

questions.stem: What is the purpose of a scheduler in an OS?
options: Decide which process runs next and for how long
questions.explanation: Scheduling allocates CPU time fairly and handles priorities.

questions.stem: Why are switches more efficient than hubs on a LAN?
options: Switches forward data only to the intended device using MAC addresses
Switches remove the need for NICs
questions.explanation: Switches reduce unnecessary traffic by sending frames to the correct port/device.

questions.stem: Why is Wi‑Fi often less reliable than Ethernet?
options: Wi‑Fi is affected by interference and signal strength
questions.explanation: Wireless signals can be disrupted by distance, walls, and interference.

questions.stem: UDP is often described as…
options: Faster but less reliable than TCP (no guaranteed delivery)
questions.explanation: UDP has low overhead; some packets may be lost.

questions.stem: A live video call prefers low latency over perfect reliability. Which transport is commonly used?
questions.explanation: Real-time media often uses UDP to reduce delay; some loss is acceptable.

questions.stem: Why are long passphrases stronger than short complex passwords?
options: They are easier to brute force
They greatly increase the number of possible combinations
questions.explanation: Brute force becomes much harder as length increases.

questions.stem: Which measure BEST reduces damage from ransomware?
questions.explanation: Backups allow recovery without paying attackers.

questions.stem: Brute force attack means…
options: Guessing many password combinations until one works
questions.explanation: Brute force tries many combinations; longer passwords are harder to crack.

questions.stem: How many different values can 5 bits represent?
questions.explanation: With n bits you can represent 2^n values. 2^5=32.

questions.stem: How many colours can be represented with a colour depth of 8 bits?
questions.explanation: 8 bits → 2^8 = 256 colours.

questions.stem: An image is 100×50 pixels, colour depth 4 bits. Minimum size (bytes)?
Audio: 44,100 Hz, 16-bit, stereo (2 channels), duration 3 s. Approx size (bytes)?
Why does increasing colour depth increase file size?
options: More bits are stored per pixel
questions.explanation: More bits per pixel means more data stored overall.

questions.stem: Which scenario is MOST suitable for lossless compression?
questions.explanation: Text and important documents usually need exact recovery.

questions.stem: Which scenario is MOST suitable for lossy compression?
options: Compressing a photo for a website
questions.explanation: Web photos often use lossy compression (JPEG) to reduce size.

questions.stem: Why is 'data minimisation' good practice?
options: Collect only the data needed for a specific purpose
questions.explanation: Collecting less data reduces risk and improves privacy compliance.

questions.stem: A company sells customer emails to advertisers without telling customers. This is mainly a…
questions.explanation: Using personal data beyond agreed purposes breaches privacy/data protection principles.

questions.stem: A photographer needs portable storage that is durable and small. Best choice?
questions.explanation: SD cards are small portable flash storage.

questions.stem: Why is an SSD generally faster than an HDD?
options: SSDs have no moving parts and use fast flash memory
questions.explanation: No moving head/platters reduces latency and improves access speed.

questions.stem: Which part of the CPU decodes instructions and controls data flow?
questions.explanation: The Control Unit interprets instructions and directs operations.

questions.stem: Which is smallest and fastest storage?
questions.explanation: Registers are the smallest and fastest storage locations.

questions.stem: Which is non-volatile?
questions.explanation: ROM is non-volatile; it keeps contents without power.

questions.stem: Which is a function of an operating system?
questions.explanation: The OS manages memory, processes, devices and files.

questions.stem: Which best describes a router?
options: Connects devices in a room only
questions.explanation: Routers connect networks and route packets between them.

questions.stem: Which is an example of malware?
questions.explanation: A virus is malicious software.

questions.stem: How many values can 3 bits represent?
questions.explanation: 2^3 = 8 possible values.

questions.stem: Which protocol is used for email sending?
questions.explanation: SMTP is used to send emails between servers.

questions.stem: Which storage is fastest for long-term file storage?
questions.explanation: SSDs are fast non-volatile storage for files.

questions.stem: What is a network?
options: Connected devices that can share resources
questions.explanation: A network is a set of connected devices that can share data and resources.

questions.stem: What is authentication?
questions.explanation: Authentication checks who you are (e.g., password, fingerprint).

questions.stem: What is secondary storage?
questions.explanation: Secondary storage stores data long-term and is non-volatile.

questions.stem: What does 'bit depth' relate to in audio?
questions.explanation: Bit depth is the number of bits used to represent each sample amplitude.

questions.stem: Which statement best describes the role of the Program Counter (PC)?
options: Stores the data currently being processed
Stores the address of the next instruction to fetch
Stores the instruction currently being decoded
questions.explanation: The Program Counter holds the memory address of the next instruction in the fetch-decode-execute cycle.

questions.stem: Why can a CPU 'bottleneck' a system even with lots of RAM and a fast SSD?
options: Because the CPU may not process instructions fast enough to keep up
Because SSDs only work with GUI
questions.explanation: If the CPU cannot execute instructions quickly enough, it limits overall system performance.

questions.stem: Which OS function deals with allocating CPU time and managing processes?
questions.explanation: Process management includes scheduling and controlling running programs.

questions.stem: A student opens a large game and their music stutters. Which OS-managed resource is most likely under pressure?
questions.explanation: Heavy apps can use lots of CPU time; the OS scheduler shares CPU time between processes.

questions.stem: Which is most likely to provide a fixed, high-bandwidth connection in a school computer lab?
questions.explanation: Ethernet is wired and typically offers higher, more stable bandwidth than Wi‑Fi in busy environments.

questions.stem: Why do switches use MAC addresses?
options: To identify countries on the internet
To decide which LAN port should receive a frame
questions.explanation: Switches learn which MAC addresses are on which ports and forward frames only where needed.

questions.stem: Which is the best description of 'social engineering'?
options: Tricking people into revealing information or performing actions
questions.explanation: Social engineering targets human behaviour rather than technical weaknesses.

questions.stem: A website database is leaked. Attackers try the leaked email/password pairs on other sites. This is called…
questions.explanation: Credential stuffing is when attackers reuse leaked login details across multiple sites.

questions.stem: A 20×30 image uses 8-bit colour depth. Minimum uncompressed file size (bytes)?
questions.explanation: Pixels=20×30=600. Bits=600×8=4,800 bits. Bytes=4,800÷8=600 bytes (ignoring headers/compression).
